# Tackling Gender Diversity In Law Firms: An Interview With Charlotte Rushton Of Thomson Reuters
## We recently sat down with Charlotte Rushton, Thomson Reuters managing director of large and medium law firms, to discuss trends in female leadership at law firms and ways to improve diversity to benefit today’s law school students. Read the interview, presented as part of the Introduction to Law School series.
By [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/author/above-the-law/)  
onOctober 20, 2016 at 1:01 PMOctober 20, 2016 at 1:03 PM
16
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/tackling-gender-diversity-in-law-firms-an-interview-with-charlotte-rushton-of-thomson-reuters/&text=Tackling%20Gender%20Diversity%20In%20Law%20Firms:%20An%20Interview%20With%20Charlotte%20Rushton%20Of%20Thomson%20Reuters)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/tackling-gender-diversity-in-law-firms-an-interview-with-charlotte-rushton-of-thomson-reuters/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/tackling-gender-diversity-in-law-firms-an-interview-with-charlotte-rushton-of-thomson-reuters/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: This article is part of the [Introduction to Law School series, powered by Thomson Reuters](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/thomson-reuters-law-school-series/). 

We recently sat down with [Charlotte Rushton](http://legalexecutiveinstitute.com/author/charlotte-rushton/), Thomson Reuters managing director of large and medium law firms, to discuss trends in female leadership at law firms and ways to improve diversity to benefit today’s law school students.

How long have you been overseeing the Large Law segment at Thomson Reuters?

Two years, since September 2014. I’ve been with Thomson Reuters for nine years; I was previously the head of the Asia Pacific and EMEA Division for our tax and accounting business.

Tell us a little bit about what the Large & Medium Law segment does.

The Large & Medium Law segment is responsible for seeing that Thomson Reuters satisfies the needs of its large and midsize law firm customers. This includes account management, customer service and overseeing a product roadmap to satisfy customer needs, as well as focusing on sales and revenue growth to ensure that Thomson Reuters continues to invest in the products that the large and midsize customers value.

What trends have you seen in recent years with respect to the roles that women are playing at large law firms?

Honestly, there doesn’t seem like there’s been an awful lot of improvement in terms of management roles. Going back to the 1980s, the proportion of women going into law school was under 40 percent; it’s now much closer to 50 percent. Looking back 15 years, it’s been close to 50 percent that whole time — law school enrollment and recruitment have proportionally been about a 50-50 split between men and women. However, if you look into higher levels of the organizations, women make up approximately 18 percent of equity partners in the Am Law 200 and 4 percent of firm-wide managing partners. While these numbers are not unusual in business in general, the situation seems starkly bad in law firms in terms of getting women up the ranks.

Have the leadership numbers changed at all as female law school enrollment has gone up from 40 percent to 50 percent?

It has improved, but only very slightly. If you look at the last 15 years — the percentage of female equity partners was 16 percent in 2001, 17 percent in 2006, 18 percent in 2016 — so it has gone up 2 percent in 15 years. It will be a long time before we ever reach parity at that rate. Recent statistics from analysts looking at similar data in corporations have estimated that, at the current rate, it will take approximately 100 years to get to parity.

Are there other aspects of law firms that are catching up more quickly on the gender equality front?

Clients and general counsel of corporations have started to pay real attention to equality and diversity on the teams they hire. The hope is that this will start to drive change within the law firms. Thomson Reuters has launched an initiative called [Transforming Women’s Leadership in the Law](http://legalexecutiveinstitute.com/transforming-womens-leadership-in-law/), which strives to connect our clients from both the law firm and the general counsel sides. We run a series of programs to get both sides of the equation together to talk about how they can work together to facilitate change.

Within law firms, we have seen a focus on coaching, mentoring, and flexible working arrangements, which are all valuable — but influence from the clients is what can really help push diversity forward. The initiative has been really well received; the women on the general counsel side really want to help their counterparts on the law firm side bring in their business, and this helps open the door to that.

Where do you think the efforts would be best focused within the firms themselves in order to try to bring about change?

There’s no silver bullet, but in looking at other similar professions like accounting or consulting, the key thing is that they’ve really focused on the issue, through diversity initiatives and getting the whole firm involved to fix the problem. The one thing we’ve been very clear about in our initiatives is that it’s not about fixing the women, it’s about fixing the processes. So shining a light on it is step No. 1. Starting right from the managing partner down through the ranks, the firm needs to be committed to making diversity real.

After that, it’s a matter of adopting programs that can help with that, like flexible working arrangements or alternative career paths that are not seen as taking the easy option, where the possibility of becoming partner is still very real. Firms have to make some structural changes to really make change happen. Perhaps most importantly, it’s crucial to have the men involved — it can’t only be the women leading the women’s initiative.

The gender pay gap has taken center stage in recent months, and the call for equal pay is at an all-time high. Has this had any effect on the availability of leadership roles for women at law firms?

I speak to a lot of managing partners about this issue, and, without exception, they all want to make improvements. I do think it’s a really good time for women in law firms to really step up — they’re in a good position to fight for change because there’s such a spotlight on the issue right now. Firm management knows diversity and equality are good for business because clients are demanding it. And everyone knows that diversity of thought is good for case outcomes and the work you produce for clients.

Why is it important for law firms to have women in upper management roles?

From a business perspective, obviously it’s important because the clients are asking for it. You need to be able to satisfy those client needs. We’re seeing a lot more RFPs now that specifically request a diversity breakdown of the team that will be handling the client’s work.

It’s also necessary to have diversity of thought and approach in terms of how the firm is run and how the cases are run. We’re currently trying to do some work with McKinsey specifically related to law firms, but studies they’ve conducted in corporations have shown higher earnings for companies with more female executives. They saw a 66 percent increase in earnings for companies that were in the top quartile for number of female executives, as opposed to those companies that don’t have female executives.

Finally, it’s important for the younger women coming in to be able to look up and see that it’s possible to get to the top of the firm or be a partner. They need to have role models and sponsors and coaches who can show them how to do it.

With respect to showing a commitment to diversity, what factors should female law school graduates look for in potential employers?

First, look to see if there are senior women in the firm, and how many. Second, look to see if they’re focused on diversity and interested in it — do they have diversity programs, do they talk about diversity, does the managing partner speak about diversity being important? Third, look to see if the men are involved or if it’s just all about the women. If you see the [men supporting and driving advancement](http://legalexecutiveinstitute.com/events/engaging-male-champions/) for everyone in the firm, that’s a real bonus.

What advice would you give to women who are considering law school or are about to graduate and enter the legal market?

Go for it. It’s a tough and demanding career, but it’s really rewarding.

In terms of specific advice, try to be better at self-promotion. Speak in terms of “I” rather than “we;” get out of your comfort zone and talk about yourself. Focus on relationship-building, which is something that I think that starts in law school and continues through your whole career. Being able to bring in a book of business is ultimately how you progress once you’ve proven you’re a good attorney. It’s never too soon to start the networking and business-building part of the job.

Women can polish business development skills and work on developing client relationships right from law school. The connections you make there can become your book of business in the future. Surveys show that there’s a gap between men and women in terms of bringing in business, and it’s important to address that early on.

Most of all, have fun and take some risks!

Stay tuned for the next post in our [Introduction to Law School](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/thomson-reuters-law-school-series/), a series powered by Thomson Reuters.

####Topics

# Former Associate Hits Biglaw Firm With Racial Discrimination Case After 'Dehumanizing' Email
## The complaint alleges the firm argued that it's not discrimination if the partner treats everyone terribly!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 18, 2024 at 1:13 PMJanuary 18, 2024 at 12:44 PM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-associate-hits-biglaw-firm-with-racial-discrimination-case-after-dehumanizing-email/&text=Former%20Associate%20Hits%20Biglaw%20Firm%20With%20Racial%20Discrimination%20Case%20After%20‘Dehumanizing’%20Email)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-associate-hits-biglaw-firm-with-racial-discrimination-case-after-dehumanizing-email/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/former-associate-hits-biglaw-firm-with-racial-discrimination-case-after-dehumanizing-email/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Former Troutman Pepper associate Gita Sankano filed a discrimination claim against her former employer in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The filing alleges Sankano, the D.C. office’s only Black female attorney suffered racial discrimination and retaliation in violation of Section 1981 of the Civil Rights Act of 1866 and the Washington, D.C., Human Rights Act.

The complaint alleges Sankano received positive reviews for her work in the Multifamily Housing Group in 2020 and 2021, but this changed after a senior partner retired and she began working for partner Matthew Bowsher. As [ reported by](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2024/01/17/troutman-pepper-sued-for-racial-discrimination-by-former-associate/) Law.com:

“Almost immediately Ms. Sankano began receiving belittling comments from Mr. Bowsher,” the suit claims, including “aggressive emails questioning her cognitive ability.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Sankano alleges that she received an “outrageously demeaning, dehumanizing, and demoralizing email” from Bowsher, and was fired when she complained about the behavior.

The email, included in the complaint, begins: “I’m concerned that you thought you were ‘clear’. In fact, you were the opposite of clear. And the fact that you still don’t see this upon further reflection, even after I’ve taken the time to point it out, is what worries me.”

“This is very basic, elementary communication. This has nothing to do with training, or understanding of multifamily transactional law, this is daily required functioning,” the email reads. “I am taking 20 minutes out of my morning right now to explain to you, in very clear objective detailed analysis, that when I see something like this, where it is so undeniably evident that you’ve made an obvious and surprising error, and you’re saying that you still don’t see the error even after I’ve taken the time to point it out to you, and you’re still saying you’ve done nothing wrong … I really just don’t know what more I can say here.”

After receiving the email, Sankano filed a complaint with HR. The retaliation the plaintiff says she received after complaining about the email from Bowsher forms the backbone of the complaint. The filing alleges the firm took “77 days to ‘investigate’ Mr. Bowsher’s discriminatory email.” The result of said investigation, according to the complaint, was that “while Mr. Bowsher’s email on August 3, 2023, was ‘inappropriate,’ it was not racist … they found that Mr. Bowsher treated people at his prior job in the same way, and thus he was not singling out Ms. Sankano.”

Listen, arguing the partner in question is a nondenominational asshole is certainly one defense, but maybe not the slam dunk you want it to be.

The complaint goes on to claim that the firm dismissed her as retaliation for her complaint.

“The purported basis for Ms. Sankano’s termination was performance, but this is a completely preposterous explanation,” the suit continues, providing multiple examples of Sankano’s positive work reviews garnered throughout her term at Troutman Pepper. “In the weeks leading up to Ms. Sankano’s termination she never received any negative comments regarding her work. In fact, during this time, Ms. Sankano accepted an award on behalf of the firm and even had discussions with firm leadership regarding being out on the ‘partner track.’”

Through a representative, the firm denied the allegations, “Ms. Sankano’s employment was terminated for legitimate, nondiscriminatory reasons based solely on her performance. We will defend ourselves vigorously in this case.”

The plaintiff is represented by Wigdor Law. Partner Michael Willemin offered this statement on the case, “It is pathetic that in this day and age law firms and other professional services firms continue to discriminate against Black women and, even more so, that they are unwilling to be the least bit introspective and remedy discrimination where it exists. Instead, firms all too often reflexively retaliate against women of color who, like Ms. Sankano, are brave enough to report discrimination in the workplace.”

Sankano also made a statement about her reasons for filing the case, “I’m filing this lawsuit to bring attention to the discrimination that Black female attorneys at Troutman Pepper, and Black professionals everywhere, continue to experience even now in 2024, as well as the callous disregard with which they are often treated when they push for workplace equality.”

# Will Cravath's Bigger Bonuses Be Big Enough To Make Associates Stay Put?
## And will these bonuses convince them to return to the office?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 23, 2021 at 2:14 PMNovember 23, 2021 at 2:03 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/will-cravaths-bigger-bonuses-be-big-enough-to-make-associates-stay-put/&text=Will%20Cravath’s%20Bigger%20Bonuses%20Be%20Big%20Enough%20To%20Make%20Associates%20Stay%20Put?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/will-cravaths-bigger-bonuses-be-big-enough-to-make-associates-stay-put/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/will-cravaths-bigger-bonuses-be-big-enough-to-make-associates-stay-put/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The annual bonus used to be pretty good at retention, but now breaking it up into seasonal bonuses just makes it all the more difficult for an associate to leave.

Firms are evaluating, ‘How do we keep associates? How do we get them to come back into the office?’ Bonuses could be a factor to that. There are still a significant number, whether it’s a majority or just a strong minority, that are not excited about going to the office.

— [Josh Holt](https://www.linkedin.com/in/joshuarholt/), founder of associate compensation tracker [Biglaw Investor](https://www.biglawinvestor.com/), commenting on the latest [year-end bonus scale](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/cravath-to-pay-115-000-bonuses-for-associates-to-start-season), which was announced earlier this week by [Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/first-mover-on-bonus/), and is expected to be followed by many other Biglaw firms.

# Vault Rankings: Top Law Firms By Practice Area And Region (2021)
## Which law firms are considered to be at the top of their game? Let's find out!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 10, 2020 at 1:45 PMSeptember 10, 2020 at 1:31 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-rankings-top-law-firms-by-practice-area-and-region-2021/&text=Vault%20Rankings:%20Top%20Law%20Firms%20By%20Practice%20Area%20And%20Region%20(2021))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-rankings-top-law-firms-by-practice-area-and-region-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-rankings-top-law-firms-by-practice-area-and-region-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Earlier this week, Vault released its closely watched rankings of the [nation’s 100 most prestigious law firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/vault-100-rankings-the-most-prestigious-law-firms-in-america-2021/). It was there that we learned Cravath held onto its title as the most prestigious firm in America for the fifth year in a row, and that Skadden had edged out Wachtell from the No. 2 spot for the first time in the history of the rankings — by just 0.010 points.

But what if your firm wasn’t top-ranked in the Vault 100? Perhaps your firm isn’t the most prestigious, but that doesn’t mean it doesn’t have clout. Some law firms reign supreme when it comes to certain practice areas, and others are known to dominate entire regions of the country.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Which law firms are considered to be at the top of their game by practice area and region? Let’s find out!

For the purposes of the practice area ranking, Vault asked associates to vote for up to three firms they think of as the strongest in their own practice area, and the overall ranking indicates the firms that received the highest percentage of votes. Associates were not allowed to vote for their own firm, which we’re sure made many recovering gunners very, very sad. Current gunners may find this list useful if they know which area they’d prefer to practice in. Pay attention, prospective laterals, because this is useful for you, too.

We’ve picked out a dozen of the practice areas that were ranked by Vault (you can see the full list [here](https://www.vault.com/best-companies-to-work-for/law/best-law-firms-in-each-practice-area/antitrust)):

Appellate Litigation: Gibson Dunn

Bankruptcy: Weil Gotshal

Energy, Oil and Gas: Vinson & Elkins

General Commercial Litigation: Quinn Emanuel

General Corporate Practice: Cravath

Intellectual Property: Fish & Richardson

International: White & Case

Labor and Employment: Littler Mendelson

Private Equity: Kirkland & Ellis

Real Estate: Fried Frank

Securities: Davis Polk

Tax: Skadden

Next up, we’ve got a ranking that matters to those who think “location, location, location” is the most important thing in life. Vault’s regional rankings are based on votes tabulated from associates who were asked to rate firms on a 1 to 10 scale based on their prestige within the region.

Here’s the list of prestige by region from Vault (you can see the full list [here](https://www.vault.com/best-companies-to-work-for/law/best-law-firms-in-each-us-region/atlanta)):

Atlanta: King & Spalding

Boston: Ropes & Gray

Chicago: Kirkland & Ellis

Florida: Holland & Knight

Mid-Atlantic: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom

Midwest: Jones Day

Mountain States: Gibson Dunn & Crutcher

New York: Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz

New York – Midsize: Pryor Cashman

Northern California: Morrison & Foerster

Pacific Northwest: Perkins Coie

South Atlantic: King & Spalding

Southern California: Latham & Watkins

Texas: Vinson & Elkins

Texas – Midsize: Susman Godfrey

Washington, DC: Covington & Burling

Congratulations to the firms that moved up in this year’s practice area and regional rankings, and congratulations to all the firms that made the cut in the first place. It must be nice to see which firms associates consider as their peers in prestige, and it must be even nicer for partners to know whose pricing models they need to undercut the next time around.

# Gibson Dunn Looks Into Strip Club Visit... Still Bills Less Than Champagne Room
## The rainmaker meets making it rain.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 20, 2022 at 11:45 AMSeptember 20, 2022 at 11:24 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/gibson-dunn-looks-into-strip-club-visit-still-bills-less-than-champagne-room/&text=Gibson%20Dunn%20Looks%20Into%20Strip%20Club%20Visit…%20Still%20Bills%20Less%20Than%20Champagne%20Room)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/gibson-dunn-looks-into-strip-club-visit-still-bills-less-than-champagne-room/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/gibson-dunn-looks-into-strip-club-visit-still-bills-less-than-champagne-room/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A whistleblower at Santander alleged that senior bankers went to a strip club and pressured junior colleagues to come along. This is the sort of inappropriate Mad Men-era behavior that law firms stamped out years ago. Banks, on the other hand, keep having allegations like these fall in their laps.

Santander hired Gibson Dunn to investigate the matter in what must have been a nightmare for whoever monitors the “research” billing code over there. In all seriousness, this is an employment discrimination matter when managers put juniors in the position of being rewarded explicitly or implicitly if they’re comfortable with some tawdry bonding and while leaving out those that aren’t.

But did the bank really need Biglaw for this one? It’s a testament to the blinkered thinking in legal departments that when faced with an incredibly mundane — except the subject matter — employment inquiry, the client still went with a top-dollar firm. But this was a golden opportunity to branch out from the existing stable of counsel and find a high-quality mid-sized or boutique firm to deal with the matter at a lower price point. Maybe Gibson Dunn handled this as a courtesy. Though if they did, we’d caution Santander that it’s because of a more lucrative relationship, not because Gibson Dunn is really into you.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Especially since the investigation seems to have fizzled.

The law firm interviewed several people involved in the night out and concluded there had not been explicit pressure exerted on junior staff members, the source added.

Shocking that discrimination didn’t take the form of “okay, everyone who follows me to the club gets promoted!” That’s generally not how that works, which is why most entities put “don’t take people to strip clubs” in their employee handbook to preemptively avoid these issues.

Maybe rewriting the handbook would be a good task for outside counsel.

# Biglaw Associates Are Being Rushed Back To Work In The Office -- But Why?
## What's going to be so different about the office now than before the pandemic?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 17, 2021 at 1:43 PMNovember 17, 2021 at 7:25 PM
23
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associates-are-being-rushed-back-to-work-in-the-office-but-why/&text=Biglaw%20Associates%20Are%20Being%20Rushed%20Back%20To%20Work%20In%20The%20Office%20—%20But%20Why?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associates-are-being-rushed-back-to-work-in-the-office-but-why/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-associates-are-being-rushed-back-to-work-in-the-office-but-why/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Aren’t you excited to head back to the office? Oh, you’re not. But don’t you remember all of the super important professional development and mentorship opportunities you had when your the was packed full of associates and partners? Oh, no, you don’t. You must’ve had so much fun though when the office was hopping and full of life, right? Oh, it… it never really was. Aha. Interesting.

Wouldn’t you be surprised to learn that Biglaw offices were never really that full to begin with before the pandemic? It sure sounds like law firm leaders have some explaining to do.

Although many Biglaw firms are now mandating office work to return their highly animated in-person working environments that once pushed occupancy limits, a description like that wasn’t exactly a reality for the average firm. In fact, law firm consultant Kent Zimmerman of the Zeughauser Group [says](https://twitter.com/kentzimmermann/status/1460635670087712776) that “[m]any large US firms actually had less than 50% daily average attendance before the pandemic.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So what is the point of all this? [Law.com’s](https://www.law.com/2021/11/17/law-com-trendspotter-smart-law-firms-are-acknowledging-that-idyllic-pre-pandemic-office-culture-is-a-myth/) Zach Needles has some thoughts:

The good news is that, as firms begin to urge attorneys back to the office for at least part of each week, the smart organizations are recognizing that the goal should not be to get back to normal, but rather to create a new, better normal in which in-person work serves a unique function.

The bad news is that not all of those organizations know what that function should be.

Many firms are trying to make the office a destination for associates in an attempt to “justify the commute.” Some are doing that by providing free meals and snacks and lightening up on their formal dress codes. Needles argues that’s not what justifying the commute for associates should mean.

What it should mean is providing opportunities for young lawyers to get quality facetime with partners and decision-makers, meaningful work and true hands-on training. Even for more senior lawyers, the goal should be have them connect with colleagues in ways that can’t easily be replicated on Zoom.

From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“The concept is trying to bring people back with a purpose, so you don’t have somebody who makes the commute, then realizes, ‘I could’ve done the exact same thing from home.’ I think that’ll be a challenge, and part of getting used to the return,” [said](https://www.law.com/2021/09/22/firms-will-bring-people-back-to-the-office-but-they-wont-be-the-same/) Joe Krasovec, managing partner at Schiff Hardin. “You’re not just showing up everyday. It’s not just a ritual. It’s, ‘OK, what am I doing today? Who is going to be there? What’s the interaction, and how will that make it better?’”

What is your law firm doing to make sure that when you do arrive to work in the office after all these months, it’ll be worth your while? Please let us know. You can [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) or text us (646-820-8477). Thanks.

# Top 5 Biglaw Firm Makes It Rain On Associates With $215K Milbank Salary Match
## Money, money, money! Biglaw associates will see lots of it this winter.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 24, 2022 at 12:43 PMJanuary 24, 2022 at 12:32 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/baker-raise-2022/&text=Top%205%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Makes%20It%20Rain%20On%20Associates%20With%20$215K%20Milbank%20Salary%20Match)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/baker-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/baker-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Associates at Biglaw firms that weren’t among the first to match [Milbank’s new salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/01/alert-milbank-announces-salary-scale-increases-to-kick-off-the-new-year/) certainly had a long weekend — even associates at some of the wealthiest law firms in the country. Luckily, one of our nation’s Biglaw behemoths just came through for its U.S. associates.

Baker McKenzie, a firm that brought in $2,899,834,000 gross revenue in 2020, making it the No. 4 firm in the latest Am Law 100 ranking, announced today that it would be matching the new prevailing salary scale. The firm matched the moment Davis Polk one-upped Milbank during the [last round of raises](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-make-it-rain-on-associates-with-a-205k-davis-polk-salary-match/), and this time, took the weekend to let the dust to settle before matching.

Here’s Baker McKenzie’s new salary scale:



The firm’s salary increases are retroactive to January 1, and associates will see more money in their February 11 paychecks. Congratulations to everyone!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Baker McKenzie.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Milbank) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Milbank”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Bonus News Came Upon A Midnight Cleary
## All right, it's not midnight but it's dark out.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 1, 2022 at 6:47 PMDecember 2, 2022 at 9:29 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/2022-bonuses-cleary/&text=Bonus%20News%20Came%20Upon%20A%20Midnight%20Cleary)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/2022-bonuses-cleary/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/2022-bonuses-cleary/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Thursday night is ending with a bang as more firms announce holiday bonuses and solidify the market standard.

This time it’s my old firm, Cleary Gottlieb, informing all associates in good standing on its U.S. pay scale that they will be getting a little extra in their December 23, 2022 paychecks.

In accordance with our usual practice, let’s point out that Cleary brought in $1,418,818,000 for 2021, placing 29th on the Am Law 100.

Without further ado, lets show those numbers!



Full memo on the next page.

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Joe Patrice](http://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is a senior editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joepatrice@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news. Joe also serves as a [Managing Director at RPN Executive Search](https://www.rpnexecsearch.com/josephpatrice).

# Be Nice To Your Interns; One Day They Will Be Attorneys
## In a profession where reputation matters so much, small things can make a big difference.
By [Stephen R. Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/stephenwilliams/)  
onAugust 3, 2017 at 11:32 AMAugust 3, 2017 at 11:34 AM
20
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/be-nice-to-your-interns-one-day-they-will-be-attorneys/&text=Be%20Nice%20To%20Your%20Interns;%20One%20Day%20They%20Will%20Be%20Attorneys)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/be-nice-to-your-interns-one-day-they-will-be-attorneys/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/be-nice-to-your-interns-one-day-they-will-be-attorneys/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As summer sadly begins to draw to a close, I write to offer a humble reminder to my in-house and Biglaw colleagues alike: be nice to your interns (or externs, summer associates, or whatever you call them in your organization; in my workplace, they’re law clerks).

Sure, on a basic human level, it is the right thing to do. They have likely spent the last few months performing menial tasks with minimum thanks. The least we can do is send them off with a proper good-bye.

But on a more selfish note, your failure to do so could come back to haunt you in the future.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Without a doubt, any law clerk worth their salt has likely let you know they want a job after they graduate. If you are in a Biglaw firm, and the clerk has managed to avoid any catastrophic errors or getting too drunk at an office outing, there is a good choice they will receive an offer of employment and join you as a colleague in a matter of months. Likewise, if you are in-house and grow fond of your clerk, you will probably attempt to hire them after they graduate.

In either scenario, do you really want your former clerk spending his or her first days in the office recounting to his now colleagues just how big of a jerk you were when they were nobodies?

Even if the clerk has proven time and again they are not suited for post-graduation employment with your specific employer, it is still worth your while to be kind to them on their way out the door. While you may not want to hire that particular clerk, you may be interested in hiring a friend of theirs from school.

And if one thing is certain, it is that law students talk. Having a former clerk sing your praises only helps with current and future recruiting efforts. Likewise, having a clerk share horror stories of how you berated them for hours on end for taking a Friday off so they could attend a funeral will likely limit your future applicant pool. While we may think it unfair, the words of a perceived incompetent clerk matter amongst their peers.

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Finally, even if you never plan to hire your clerk, or could not care less what they tell their friends back at school, keep in mind that the law clerk will likely be an attorney practicing in your local community in just a few short years.

Receiving a call or email from a former clerk, now turned opposing counsel, is bound to go more smoothly when you both parted amicably. And again, not to beat a dead horse, but that former clerk and now attorney can either choose to share fond or foul memories of their time with you to his new colleagues.

In a profession where your reputation matters, even these small things can make a big difference.

So before those clerks whose names you’ll barely remember return for the fall semester, feed them and thank them. Take them out to lunch, listen to their stories from the summer, and tell them how much you valued their time and their work. Even if you ignored them all summer, there is still time to make a good lasting impression.

Besides, you never know which of them might grow up and become a judge.

# Who In Biglaw Is Most Excited To Go Back To The Office?
## The breakdown may surprise you!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 30, 2021 at 1:44 PMJuly 30, 2021 at 1:13 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/who-in-biglaw-is-most-excited-to-go-back-to-the-office/&text=Who%20In%20Biglaw%20Is%20Most%20Excited%20To%20Go%20Back%20To%20The%20Office?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/who-in-biglaw-is-most-excited-to-go-back-to-the-office/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/who-in-biglaw-is-most-excited-to-go-back-to-the-office/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I speak with Stacey Breen, Managing Director at Major Lindsay & Africa, about the twists and turns of her career that led her to her role at MLA, and the motivation behind their recent Return to Office Survey. We discuss the most surprising results of the survey, including generational differences in pandemic experiences. Additionally, we talk about some of the challenges women faced during COVID and what the industry can do to fix them as we return to the office.

The Jabot podcast is an offshoot of the Above the Law brand focused on the challenges women, people of color, LGBTQIA, and other diverse populations face in the legal industry. Our name comes from none other than the Notorious Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the jabot (decorative collar) she wore when delivering dissents from the bench. It’s a reminder that even when we aren’t winning, we’re still a powerful force to be reckoned with.

Happy listening!


Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Featured Podcast](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/featured-podcast/), [The Jabot Podcast](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/the-jabot-podcast/), [Unprecedented](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/unprecedented/), [Unprecedented Podcasts](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/unprecedented-podcasts/)

# The Biglaw Firms That Provided The Best Client Service During The Pandemic
## Which firms are among the best of the best?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 15, 2021 at 11:46 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-biglaw-firms-that-provided-the-best-client-service-during-the-pandemic/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Firms%20That%20Provided%20The%20Best%20Client%20Service%20During%20The%20Pandemic)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-biglaw-firms-that-provided-the-best-client-service-during-the-pandemic/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/the-biglaw-firms-that-provided-the-best-client-service-during-the-pandemic/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Which Biglaw firms are most beloved by general counsel for their superior client service? If that seems like it was a steep hill to climb during the pandemic, that’s because it was. The BTI Consulting Group set to find out which firms handled the task with ease with its latest ranking, the Client Service A-Team. In case you’re unfamiliar with this ranking, it measures the top 30 law firms corporate counsel identify as delivering the very best in terms of client service.

To compile the ranking, BTI Consulting spoke with almost 250 legal decision-makers who were asked to name firms that excelled in 17 different client-service-related activities, seven of which reigned supreme above all overs, including: mobilizing resources quickly, fielding the absolute best team, quickly assessing the situation, a commitment to help, delivering value for the dollar, client focus, and understanding the client’s business.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So, which firms are considered the best of the best when it comes to client service? Per BTI Consulting, the firms that made the latest top 30 ranking performed 9 to 15 times better than the typical firm in terms of client service. The ranking notes, “Each firm earns their performance the hard way: delivering the best.”

To make the [Client Service A-Team](https://bticonsulting.com/bti-client-service-a-team-2021-survey-of-law-firm-client-service-performance), the following 30 Biglaw firms were mentioned most often across all categories:

- Jones Day
- DLA Piper
- Gibson Dunn
- Arnold & Porter
- Sidley
- McGuireWoods
- Littler
- Kirkland & Ellis
- Mayer Brown
- Morgan Lewis
- Faegre Drinker
- King & Spalding
- Latham & Watkins
- Duane Morris
- Jackson Lewis
- Skadden
- Davis Polk
- Dentons
- Ogletree Deakins
- Baker Botts
- Folen & Lardner
- Sheppard Mullin
- Shook Hardy & Bacon
- McDermott Will & Emery
- Covington
- Holland & Knight
- Eversheds Sutherland
- Greenberg Traurig
- Pillsbury
- Seyfarth Shaw
During the course of the pandemic, 70 firms improved their client-service performance at more than twice the rate of all other law firms, ranging from awesome improvement (five stars) to impressive improvement (one star). Out of those 70, only five firms received the awesome improvement ranking. They are:

If attorneys at your firm make more of an effort to better understand your clients’ businesses and provide them with more frequent updates, then you may find your place of work on this list next time around. Congratulations to all 30 firms that made the Client Service A-List. You’ve proven yourselves to be outstanding when it comes to making corporate clients happy, and that’s worth celebrating.

# Why Would Anyone Work In Philadelphia?
## Where should you work?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 24, 2016 at 5:45 PMOctober 24, 2016 at 3:14 PM
37
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/why-would-anyone-work-in-philadelphia/&text=Why%20Would%20Anyone%20Work%20In%20Philadelphia?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/why-would-anyone-work-in-philadelphia/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/why-would-anyone-work-in-philadelphia/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Putting aside the access to cheesesteaks, these people boo Santa Claus. What can possibly be great about taking your legal talents to Broad Street?

Joe and Elie talked to The Legal Blitz’s Steven Silver about working in the Philadelphia market. We discuss Philadelphia’s appeal for plaintiffs’ firms, it’s key client industries, and the virtues of living in a big city without the costs of Manhattan.

Plus there are more than a couple firms paying New York wages for a cheaper standard of living and that can’t hurt.

text:
[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Thursday, July 13, 2017
“Silver May Start ‘Parade of Horribles’ Out of McDonnell Case, Critics Say”: Alan Feuer of The New York Times has [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/nyregion/sheldon-silver-bob-mcdonnell.html).

Posted at [11:23 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72196) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Timber giant loses in court again over $100 million Moonlight Fire settlement”: Sam Stanton of The Sacramento Bee has [an article](http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/article161204183.html) that begins, “A federal appeals court on Thursday rejected efforts by Sierra Pacific Industries to back out of a $100 million settlement over the massive Moonlight Fire that it claims was based on fraud and deception by government prosecutors in Sacramento.”

You can access today’s ruling of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit](http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov) at [this link](http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2017/07/13/15-15799.pdf).

And in earlier coverage of the case at “Above the Law,” David Lat had a post titled “[A Federal Judge And His Twitter Account: A Cautionary Tale; Do you think this judge crossed the line in his use of social media?](http://abovethelaw.com/2015/11/a-federal-judge-and-his-twitter-account-a-cautionary-tale/)”

Posted at [9:03 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72195) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Md. redistricting case could stall while Supreme Court hears Wisconsin case”: Josh Hicks of The Washington Post has [this report](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/md-politics/md-redistricting-case-could-stall-while-supreme-court-hears-wisconsin-case/2017/07/13/623ccdaa-6013-11e7-a4f7-af34fc1d9d39_story.html).

Posted at [8:33 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72194) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Four of Trump’s judicial nominees clear Senate committee”: Alex Swoyer of The Washington Times has [this report](http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jul/13/four-donald-trump-judicial-nominees-clear-senate-c/).

And last week, Melissa Nann Burke of The Detroit News reported that “[Trump’s Michigan judicial nominee hits a snag](http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2017/07/04/trump-michigan-larsen-judicial-nominee-stabenow-peters/103427820/).”

Posted at [8:30 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72193) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Former Pitt neuroresearcher Robert Ferrante appeals conviction for killing wife”: Paula Reed Ward of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette has [this report](http://www.post-gazette.com/local/city/2017/07/13/robert-Ferrante-cyanide-poisoning-autumn-klein-appeal-conviction-pennsylvania-superior-court-pitt-neuroresearcher/stories/201707130079).

Posted at [8:15 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72192) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Sheldon Silver’s 2015 Corruption Conviction Is Overturned”: Benjamin Weiser of The New York Times has [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/nyregion/sheldon-silvers-conviction-is-overturned.html).

Matthew Hamilton of The Times Union of Albany, New York reports that “[Appeals court overturns conviction of Sheldon Silver; Judges cite McDonnell decision in ruling in former Assembly speaker’s case](http://www.timesunion.com/7day-state/article/Appeals-court-overturns-conviction-of-Sheldon-11285874.php).”

Kaja Whitehouse and Lia Eustachewich of The New York Post report that “[Sheldon Silver’s corruption conviction is overturned](http://nypost.com/2017/07/13/sheldon-silvers-corruption-conviction-is-overturned/)” and “[Prosecutors vow to retry Silver on corruption charges](http://nypost.com/2017/07/13/prosecutors-vow-to-retry-silver-on-corruption-charges/).”

Victoria Bekiempis, Glenn Blain, and Larry McShane of The New York Daily News report that “[Ex-Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver’s 2015 corruption conviction overturned](http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/ex-assembly-speaker-sheldon-silver-2015-conviction-overturned-article-1.3323270).”

Jonathan Stempel and Joseph Ax of Reuters report that “[Ex-New York Assembly Speaker Silver has conviction voided, faces retrial](http://www.reuters.com/article/us-new-york-corruption-silver-idUSKBN19Y1N9).”

David Klepper and Larry Neumeister of The Associated Press report that “[Conviction of ex-NY Assembly speaker tossed; retrial sought](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_EX_ASSEMBLY_SPEAKER_TRIAL?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).”

And Bill Mahoney of Politico.com reports that “[Appeals court overturns Sheldon Silver conviction](http://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2017/07/13/silvers-conviction-vacated-113367).”

You can access today’s ruling of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit](http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov) at [this link](http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov/decisions/isysquery/e9348cc9-34b9-4c6f-af5b-310677bcd20f/5/doc/16-1615_opn.pdf#xml=http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov/decisions/isysquery/e9348cc9-34b9-4c6f-af5b-310677bcd20f/5/hilite/).

Posted at [2:08 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72191) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Yes, Trump Can Accept Gifts”: [Josh Blackman](http://www.stcl.edu/about-us/faculty/josh-blackman/) and [Seth Barrett Tillman](https://www.maynoothuniversity.ie/people/seth-barrett-tillman) have [this essay](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/13/opinion/trump-france-bastille-emoluments.html?_r=0) online at The New York Times.

Posted at [12:00 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72190) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Benched: Abortion, Terrorists, Drones, Crooks, Supreme Court, Kennedy, Nixon, Demi Moore, and Other Tales from the Life of a Federal Judge.” Senior [Second Circuit](http://www.ca2.uscourts.gov) Judge [Jon O. Newman](https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/newman-jon-ormond) has written [a new book](https://www.wshein.com/catalog/?title=benched&auth=&publ=&years=Year&titledesc=&heinnumber=&isbn=&issn=&major_subject=&periodical=&series=&format=&submit=), and you can learn more about it [here](https://www.wshein.com/media/brochures/1004941.pdf?d=20170712&utm_source=William+S.+Hein+%26+Co.%2C+Inc.+%26+HeinOnline&utm_campaign=a8fb303412-Benched_Email_2017_07_11&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_74dc9f7099-a8fb303412-238376893) and [here](http://heinonline.org/HeinDocs/BenchedTOC.pdf?utm_source=William+S.+Hein+%26+Co.%2C+Inc.+%26+HeinOnline&utm_campaign=a8fb303412-Benched_Email_2017_07_11&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_74dc9f7099-a8fb303412-238376893).

Posted at [11:54 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72189) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Why the U.S. could see more executions this year”: Mark Berman of The Washington Post has [this report](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2017/07/12/why-the-u-s-could-see-more-executions-this-year/).

Posted at [11:48 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72188) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Uncertainty swirls around Trump nominations; White House delay in floating names for Oregon seat on powerful U.S. Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and top federal prosecutor job has sparked speculation U.S. Rep. Greg Walden’s picks are not a sure thing”: Nick Budnick of the Portland (Ore.) Tribune has [this report](http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/365939-246838-uncertainty-swirls-around-trump-nominations).

Posted at [11:44 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72187) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

Posted at [11:40 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72186) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Developing the Court’s Precedent 2016”: Adam Feldman has [this post](https://empiricalscotus.com/2017/07/12/precedent-2016/) at his “Empirical SCOTUS” blog.

Posted at [11:32 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/07/13/#72185) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# Travel Story Contest Champion
## We know what travel story you find the craziest.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 10, 2017 at 11:32 AM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/travel-story-contest-champion/&text=Travel%20Story%20Contest%20Champion)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/travel-story-contest-champion/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/travel-story-contest-champion/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Thanks to everyone for entering and then voting in our [craziest travel stories contest](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/your-craziest-travel-tales-the-finalists/). In the end, there was a breakout winner as the wildest tale of legal travel anyone heard.

Capturing 51 percent of the vote — enough to win any election anywhere except the U.S. presidency — the story of David Boies fighting a brutal snowstorm and limping home to Cravath in a wrecked rental car is our champion.

Take a second to consider that this story beat out actually traveling through a war zone.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
In any event, congratulations to the winning pair of stories, and thanks to [Blade](https://www.flyblade.com/) for putting up the prize — a helicopter trip from midtown to JFK, so you can soar over the rush hour traffic on your way to your flight.

[Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/) is an editor at Above the Law and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](http://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Law School Professor/Former Biglaw Partner Dies After Ancient Tree Falls On Home
## He's remembered as the 'rock' of his family.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 1, 2021 at 3:45 PMDecember 1, 2021 at 2:20 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/law-school-professor-former-biglaw-partner-dies-after-ancient-tree-falls-on-home/&text=Law%20School%20Professor/Former%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Dies%20After%20Ancient%20Tree%20Falls%20On%20Home)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/law-school-professor-former-biglaw-partner-dies-after-ancient-tree-falls-on-home/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/law-school-professor-former-biglaw-partner-dies-after-ancient-tree-falls-on-home/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Sad news from Encino, California, where an adjunct professor at USC Gould School of Law and Pepperdine Law, Dennis Franks, passed away Sunday night after an ancient tree — estimated as at least 500 years old and weighing 100,000 pounds — fell on his home. Franks [previously worked](https://www.linkedin.com/in/dennisbfranks/) in-house at Twentieth Century Fox and The Walt Disney Corporation. Before moving in-house, Franks was a partner at the Biglaw firm of Manatt, Phelps & Phillips.

His son [said](https://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2021/11/30/attorney-law-school-professor-dennis-franks-identified-tree-fall-encino-home/) of the family’s loss:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“He’s the rock of our family,” Kevin Franks said. “I want him remembered as like a caretaker — he took care of everyone. We’re going to love him and miss him and think about him forever.”

Franks died while reading in his “man cave,” his “happy place” converted from his son’s old bedroom. Also in the house at the time of the incident were Franks’s wife Maureen, daughter Becca, and dog Parker. They were on the first floor of the house and able to get out safely.

The ancient tree that fell on Franks’s home was protected by regulation and removal requires approval from the LA County planners. Kevin Franks[ said ](https://ktla.com/news/local-news/man-killed-when-massive-tree-crashes-through-encino-home-in-middle-of-night/)the family paid for maintenance of the tree, working with an arborist and using chains to “keep stuff from falling.”

Los Angeles Fire Department Capt. Cody Weireter indicated how unusual the incident is:

“I’ve never experienced anything like this … You’re looking at well over 100,000 pounds of a tree falling onto a home in the middle of the night,” Weireter said.

“No wind or rain … obviously unexpected, absolutely tragic tonight,” Weireter said.

Though neighbors said the tree was leaning as much as 30 degrees in recent days.

Our thoughts go out to Franks’s family, friends, and colleagues during this difficult time.

# Many Lawyers Will Be Getting Screwed This Tax Season
## You can probably kiss that refund check you were hoping for goodbye.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 8, 2019 at 11:16 AMFebruary 8, 2019 at 11:03 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/lawyers-screwed-owe-taxes/&text=Many%20Lawyers%20Will%20Be%20Getting%20Screwed%20This%20Tax%20Season)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/lawyers-screwed-owe-taxes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/lawyers-screwed-owe-taxes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘Oh no…’

Last year I got a $750 refund. And this year I owe $4,600. I guess that my assumption was that the IRS withholding tables would have been updated to some degree or my company would have done something.

— Ben Williams, a lawyer in New York City, commenting on a situation most lawyers, especially lawyers in blue states, are [dreading encountering this tax season](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/gop-tax-law-refunds_us_5c5b4885e4b00187b557d1fb). The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act capped deductions on state and local tax (SALT) payments to $10,000, and Williams said he usually pays more than three times that amount in SALT expenses. He’d hoped to use his anticipated tax refund for a vacation.

# Individual Bonus Memos At This Firm
## Things are going well at this firm... we guess.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 14, 2018 at 11:15 AMDecember 17, 2018 at 10:15 AM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/individual-bonus-memos-at-this-firm/&text=Individual%20Bonus%20Memos%20At%20This%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/individual-bonus-memos-at-this-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/individual-bonus-memos-at-this-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We love a good lockstep bonus memo. It sends a message of collegiality in an increasingly atomized world. But sometimes we can’t all get what we want. And that’s where Perkins Coie comes in.

After our most recent [shame list](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/has-your-firm-announced-bonuses-because-these-1m-ppp-firms-havent/), we’ve heard that Perkins Coie has sent around individualized memos to all associates and counsels over the last two days. We don’t have enough data points to opine on the quality of the bonuses, but the fact that people aren’t bombarding our inbox, we feel comfortable assuming they met the market because anything else in either direction would kick up a hornet’s nest.

UPDATE: It sounds like things may not be going well with these bonuses. Tipsters report lower bonuses than in past years and hearing from management that the reason is “overall compensation is up.” If true, that means Perkins Coie is using the summer’s raises to justify shorting associates on bonuses, which is the opposite of paying market.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
So if you have more insight, let us know. Otherwise, congrats.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Sunday, January 22, 2017
“Foreign Payments to Trump Firms Violate Constitution, Suit Will Claim”: Eric Lipton and Adam Liptak of The New York Times have [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/us/politics/trump-foreign-payments-constitution-lawsuit.html).

Posted at [9:52 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70215) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Blankenship conviction upheld by appeals court”: Wendy Holdren of The Register-Herald of Beckley, West Virginia has [this report](http://www.register-herald.com/news/blankenship-conviction-upheld-by-appeals-court/article_2967d299-8191-5086-a647-826d8ef1d5a7.html) on [a ruling](http://www.ca4.uscourts.gov/Opinions/Published/164193.P.pdf) that the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit](http://www.ca4.uscourts.gov) issued Thursday.

Posted at [9:40 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70214) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“D.C. Circuit Review — Reviewed: ‘The U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit will be closed on . . . January 20, 2017.'” Aaron Nielson has [this post](http://yalejreg.com/nc/d-c-circuit-review-reviewed-the-u-s-court-of-appeals-for-the-d-c-circuit-will-be-closed-on-january-20-2017/) at the “Notice & Comment” blog of the Yale Journal on Regulation.

Posted at [9:20 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70213) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“GOP eyes new push to break up California court”: Lydia Wheeler of The Hill has [an article](http://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/315354-gop-eyes-new-push-to-break-up-california-court) that begins, “Republican lawmakers are eyeing a new push to break up the California-based federal court of appeals, which is widely considered one of the most liberal courts in the country.”

Posted at [1:37 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70212) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“How Trump can use Obamacare to kill Obamacare: The same executive authority the Obama administration used to implement the law may now be used to dismantle it.” Dan Diamond of Politico.com has [this report](http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/trump-obamacare-233983).

Posted at [1:08 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70211) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Sen. Schumer willing to block Trump’s Supreme Court pick ‘if the nominee is not bipartisan and mainstream'”: Adam Edelman of The New York Daily News has [this report](http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/sen-schumer-block-trump-supreme-court-pick-article-1.2952895).

Eric Bradner of CNN.com reports that “[Schumer vows opposition to any ‘out of the mainstream’ Supreme Court pick](http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/22/politics/chuck-schumer-trump-cabinet/).”

And Mallory Shelbourne of The Hill reports that “[Schumer ready to leave Supreme Court seat open](http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/315524-schumer-ready-to-leave-ninth-supreme-court-seat-open).”

Posted at [12:58 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70210) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)
